title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5lite package provides simple, lightweight, user-friendly interface reading writing HDF5 files. designed R users want save load R objects (vectors, matrices, arrays) HDF5 file without needing understand low-level details HDF5 C API. guide walk common use case: simulating experimental data, saving HDF5 file along metadata, reading back analysis.

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: Think HDF5 file self-contained file system. ’s single file disk can hold organized hierarchy data. three important concepts : Groups: like folders directories. use organize data. Groups can contain groups create nested structure. Datasets: like files file system. dataset stores actual data, vector, matrix, multi-dimensional array. Every dataset resides inside group. Attributes: small, named pieces metadata can attach either groups datasets. perfect storing extra information like units, descriptions, configuration parameters. h5lite designed make working structure feel natural R user.

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: primary function writing data h5_write(). creates dataset inside HDF5 file automatically handles: Creating HDF5 file doesn’t exist. Creating parent groups needed (like command mkdir -p). Overwriting existing dataset path. Let’s start writing matrix simulated sensor readings dataset. ’s ! ’ve just created HDF5 file stored matrix . Helpful Tip: Notice name "experiment_1/sensor_readings". h5lite automatically created group experiment_1 creating dataset sensor_readings inside .
code: # A 3x4 matrix of sensor data sensor_data <- matrix(rnorm(12, mean = 25, sd = 0.5), nrow = 3, ncol = 4)  h5_write(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", sensor_data) #> NULL

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: default, h5lite saves numeric data double (64-bit float). need control -disk storage type efficiency, use dtype argument. Let’s save integer identifiers.
code: trial_ids <- 1L:12L h5_write(file, "experiment_1/trial_ids", trial_ids, dtype = "integer") #> NULL

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: write single value (scalar), must specify dims = NULL.
code: h5_write(file, "experiment_1/run_id", "run-abc-123", dims = NULL) #> NULL

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: Now ’ve written data, see ’s file?

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5_ls() lists objects (groups datasets) file. default, lists everything recursively. see top-level objects, use recursive = FALSE.
code: h5_ls(file) #> [1] "experiment_1"                 "experiment_1/run_id"          #> [3] "experiment_1/sensor_readings" "experiment_1/trial_ids" h5_ls(file, recursive = FALSE) #> [1] "experiment_1"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: can inspect dataset’s properties without reading data. useful large datasets. h5_dim() returns dimensions R’s standard, column-major order. h5_typeof() returns underlying HDF5 storage type.
code: dim(sensor_data) #> [1] 3 4 h5_dim(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings") #> [1] 3 4  h5_typeof(file, "experiment_1/trial_ids") #> [1] "INT"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: read data back R, use h5_read(). automatically handles transposing data HDF5’s row-major order R’s column-major order restores correct dimensions. Safety First: h5lite reads numeric HDF5 types (integers, floats, etc.) R’s numeric (double-precision) vectors. intentional design choice prevent integer overflow, common bug reading data systems.
code: read_sensor_data <- h5_read(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings")  print(read_sensor_data) #>          [,1]     [,2]     [,3]     [,4] #> [1,] 24.29998 24.99721 24.08909 24.85865 #> [2,] 25.12766 25.31078 24.87634 24.72315 #> [3,] 23.78137 25.57421 24.87790 25.31449  # Verify that the object is identical to the original all.equal(sensor_data, read_sensor_data) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: Attributes small pieces metadata attached datasets groups. perfect storing things like units, configuration parameters, version info. Let’s add attributes sensor_readings dataset. can list read attributes using h5_ls_attr() h5_read_attr().
code: # Add a scalar string attribute for units h5_write_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "units", "celsius", dims = NULL) #> NULL  # Add a numeric vector attribute for calibration coefficients h5_write_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "calibration", c(1.02, -0.5)) #> NULL h5_ls_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings") #> [1] "units"       "calibration"  units <- h5_read_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "units") print(units) #> [1] "celsius"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5lite special support R’s unique data types.

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: write R factor, h5lite automatically saves native HDF5 ENUM type, preserving integer values character labels.
code: conditions <- as.factor(sample(c("control", "treatment_A", "treatment_B"), 12, replace = TRUE))  h5_write(file, "experiment_1/conditions", conditions) #> NULL  # Let's check the on-disk type h5_typeof(file, "experiment_1/conditions") #> [1] "ENUM"  # Read it back - it's a perfect match! read_conditions <- h5_read(file, "experiment_1/conditions")  identical(conditions, read_conditions) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: store binary data, use R raw vector specify dtype = "opaque". stores data sequence bytes.
code: binary_blob <- as.raw(c(0xDE, 0xAD, 0xBE, 0xEF)) h5_write(file, "experiment_1/binary_config", binary_blob, dtype = "opaque") #> NULL  read_blob <- h5_read(file, "experiment_1/binary_config") identical(binary_blob, read_blob) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5lite follows “overwrite--default” philosophy. write existing path, old data replaced.
code: h5_read(file, "experiment_1/run_id") #> [1] "run-abc-123"  # Overwrite with a new value h5_write(file, "experiment_1/run_id", "run-xyz-987", dims = NULL) #> NULL  h5_read(file, "experiment_1/run_id") #> [1] "run-xyz-987"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: can explicitly delete datasets, groups, attributes.
code: # Delete a single dataset h5_delete(file, "experiment_1/trial_ids") #> NULL  # Delete an attribute h5_delete_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "calibration") #> NULL  # Delete an entire group and all its contents h5_delete_group(file, "experiment_1/binary_config") # This will fail, as it's a dataset #> NULL h5_create_group(file, "old_data/logs") #> NULL h5_delete_group(file, "old_data") #> NULL  h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE) #> [1] "experiment_1"                 "experiment_1/conditions"      #> [3] "experiment_1/run_id"          "experiment_1/sensor_readings" # Clean up the temporary file unlink(file)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Daniel P. Smith. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Smith D (2025). h5lite: Simplified HDF5 Interface. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://cmmr.github.io/h5lite/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {h5lite: Simplified HDF5 Interface},   author = {Daniel P. Smith},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://cmmr.github.io/h5lite/}, }

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: h5lite R package provides simple, lightweight, user-friendly interface reading writing HDF5 files. designed R users just want save load R objects (vectors, matrices, arrays) HDF5 file without needing understand low-level details. h5lite handles common tasks automatically: Saving R objects correct dimensions. Reading data back R matrices arrays. Reading writing R factor objects native HDF5 ENUM types. Automatically overwriting data creating parent groups. Writing compressed datasets. Safely reading numeric types without integer overflow. Reading writing R raw vectors. package uses HDF5 library developed HDF Group (https://www.hdfgroup.org/).

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: can install released version h5lite CRAN:
code: install.packages("h5lite")

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: API designed simple predictable.
code: library(h5lite)  file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Use h5_write() write vectors, matrices, arrays.
code: # Write a vector h5_write(file, "data/vector", 1:10, dtype = "integer")  # Write an R matrix mat <- matrix(c(1.1, 2.2, 3.3, 4.4), nrow = 2, ncol = 2) h5_write(file, "data/matrix", mat)  # Write a 3D array arr <- array(1L:24L, dim = c(2, 3, 4)) h5_write(file, "data/array", arr, dtype = "integer")  # Write a scalar (dims = NULL) h5_write(file, "scalar_string", "Hello!", dims = NULL)  # Write a factor (automatically creates an ENUM type) fac <- as.factor(c("a", "b", "a", "c")) h5_write(file, "factor_data", fac)  # Write a large vector with compression enabled h5_write(file, "compressed_data", 1:10000, compress = TRUE)

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Use h5_ls() see file structure.
code: # List all objects recursively h5_ls(file) #> [1] "data"              "data/array"        "data/matrix" #> [4] "data/vector"       "scalar_string"  # List only the top level h5_ls(file, recursive = FALSE) #> [1] "data"            "scalar_string"

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Use h5_read() read data back R. function automatically restores correct dimensions.
code: # Read the matrix mat_in <- h5_read(file, "data/matrix") print(mat_in) #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,1]  1.1  3.3 #> [2,1]  2.2  4.4  # Verify dimensions print(dim(mat_in)) #> [1] 2 2  all.equal(mat, mat_in) #> [1] TRUE

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: can easily read write metadata using attributes.
code: # Write attributes to the "data/matrix" dataset h5_write_attr(file, "data/matrix", "units", "meters", dims = NULL) h5_write_attr(file, "data/matrix", "scale", c(1.0, 1.0), dims = c(1, 2))  # List attributes h5_ls_attr(file, "data/matrix") #> [1] "units" "scale"  # Read an attribute units <- h5_read_attr(file, "data/matrix", "units") print(units) #> [1] "meters"

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Writing existing path automatically overwrites data. explicitly delete objects:
code: # Overwrite the vector h5_write(file, "data/vector", c(99, 100)) h5_read(file, "data/vector") #> [1] 99 100  # Delete the dataset h5_delete(file, "data/vector")  # Delete the attribute h5_delete_attr(file, "data/matrix", "units")  # Delete an entire group and its contents h5_delete_group(file, "data")  h5_ls(file) #> [1] "scalar_string"

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: rhdf5 (Bioconductor): powerful mature package provides comprehensive, low-level wrapper around HDF5 C API. excellent need fine-grained control file properties, chunking, compression, complex datatypes. bundles HDF5 dependency via Rhdf5lib Bioconductor package. hdf5r (CRAN): package provides modern, R6 class-based interface HDF5. also comprehensive powerful, requires users install manage separate, system-level HDF5 library, can make installation complex. h5lite: package comprehensive wrapper. “opinionated” interface focused simplicity safety common 80% use cases. h5lite prioritizes simple, R-like functional syntax (h5_read, h5_write) bundles HDF5 dependency (via hdf5lib) easy installation. Conclusion: Use rhdf5 hdf5r advanced user needs fine-grained control HDF5 file properties. Use h5lite want quickly safely save R matrices, arrays, lists HDF5 file without worrying low-level details.

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: h5lite intentionally simple complete HDF5 wrapper. focuses reading writing R’s atomic vectors, matrices, arrays. Features supported include: Writing Compressed Chunked Data: h5lite writes data simple, contiguous layout. provide options set chunking compression filters (like gzip). can, however, read data compressed another program. Compound Datatypes: HDF5’s struct-like H5T_COMPOUND type supported. h5lite read write R data frames compound types. Complex Datatypes: H5T_ENUM (enumerations/factors), H5T_BITFIELD, H5T_REFERENCE types supported. Property Lists: h5lite expose advanced property lists (e.g., setting fill values, link creation properties, etc.). need advanced features, please use rhdf5 hdf5r.

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Since h5_read converts numbers double safety, can use h5_typeof see actual -disk storage type.
code: # Write data as 32-bit floats and 16-bit integers  h5_write(file, "floats", 1:5, dtype = "float") h5_write(file, "shorts", 1:5, dtype = "short")  h5_typeof(file, "floats") #> [1] "FLOAT" h5_typeof(file, "shorts") #> [1] "SHORT" h5_typeof_attr(file, "data/matrix", "scale") #> [1] "DOUBLE"

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Use h5_dim check dimensions dataset without reading (potentially large) data.
code: h5_dim(file, "data/array") #> [1] 2 3 4

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: want create empty group structure, use h5_create_group.
code: h5_create_group(file, "/metadata/logs") h5_ls(file) #> [1] "metadata"       "metadata/logs"  "scalar_string"

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
text: Explicitly creates new group (nested groups) HDF5 file. useful creating empty group structure.

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
code: h5_create_group(file, name)

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
text: file Path HDF5 file. name full path group create (e.g., "/g1/g2").

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  h5_create_group(file, "/my/nested/group") #> NULL  h5_ls(file) #> [1] "my"              "my/nested"       "my/nested/group" unlink(file)

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
text: Deletes dataset HDF5 file.

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
code: h5_delete(file, name)

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
text: file Path HDF5 file. name full path dataset delete.

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "dset1", 1:10) #> NULL h5_write(file, "dset2", 1:5) #> NULL h5_ls(file) #> [1] "dset1" "dset2"  h5_delete(file, "dset1") #> NULL h5_ls(file) #> [1] "dset2" unlink(file)

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
text: Deletes attribute object.

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
code: h5_delete_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name path object (dataset group). attribute name attribute delete.

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "data", 1) #> NULL h5_write_attr(file, "data", "attr1", 123, dims = NULL) #> NULL h5_ls_attr(file, "data") # "attr1" #> [1] "attr1"  h5_delete_attr(file, "data", "attr1") #> NULL h5_ls_attr(file, "data") # character(0) #> character(0) unlink(file)

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
text: Deletes group objects contained within .

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
code: h5_delete_group(file, name)

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
text: file Path HDF5 file. name full path group delete (e.config. "/g1/g2").

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "/g1/g2/dset", 1:10) #> NULL h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE) # "g1" "g1/g2" "g1/g2/dset" #> [1] "g1"         "g1/g2"      "g1/g2/dset"  h5_delete_group(file, "/g1") #> NULL h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE) # character(0) #> character(0) unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
text: Returns dimensions dataset integer vector. dimensions match R-style (column-major) interpretation.

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
code: h5_dim(file, name)

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset.

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
text: Integer vector dimensions, integer(0) scalars.

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  mat <- matrix(1:10, nrow = 2, ncol = 5) h5_write(file, "matrix", mat) #> NULL  # Check dims without reading the whole dataset h5_dim(file, "matrix") # Returns c(2, 5) #> [1] 2 5  unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
text: Returns dimensions attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
code: h5_dim_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object attached . attribute Name attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
text: Integer vector dimensions, integer(0) scalars.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "data", 1) #> NULL  h5_write_attr(file, "data", "vec_attr", 1:10) #> NULL h5_dim_attr(file, "data", "vec_attr") # 10 #> [1] 10  unlink(file)

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
text: Lists names objects (datasets groups) within HDF5 file.

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
code: h5_ls(file, name = "/", recursive = TRUE)

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
text: file Path HDF5 file. name group path start listing . Defaults root group "/". recursive TRUE (default), lists objects found recursively name. FALSE, lists immediate children name.

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
text: character vector object names (relative paths).

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Create nested structure h5_write(file, "group1/data1", 1) #> NULL h5_write(file, "group1/subgroup/data2", 2) #> NULL h5_write(file, "group2/data3", 3) #> NULL  # List everything (Recursive) h5_ls(file) #> [1] "group1"                "group1/data1"          "group1/subgroup"       #> [4] "group1/subgroup/data2" "group2"                "group2/data3"           # List top level only h5_ls(file, recursive = FALSE) #> [1] "group1" "group2"  # List inside a specific group h5_ls(file, "group1") #> [1] "data1"          "subgroup"       "subgroup/data2"  unlink(file)

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
text: Lists names attributes attached specific HDF5 object.

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
code: h5_ls_attr(file, name)

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name path object (dataset group) query. Use "/" file's root attributes.

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
text: character vector attribute names.

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "data", 1) #> NULL  h5_write_attr(file, "data", "a1", 1, dims = NULL) #> NULL h5_write_attr(file, "data", "a2", 2, dims = NULL) #> NULL  h5_ls_attr(file, "data") #> [1] "a1" "a2" unlink(file)

what: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: Reads dataset HDF5 file returns R object.

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
code: h5_read(file, name)

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset (e.g., "/data/matrix").

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: numeric, character, raw vector/array.

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: Numeric datasets read numeric (double) prevent overflow. String datasets read character. 1-byte OPAQUE datasets read raw. Dimensions preserved transposed match R's column-major order.

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Write a matrix mat <- matrix(1:12, nrow = 3, ncol = 4) h5_write(file, "example_matrix", mat) #> NULL  # Read it back mat2 <- h5_read(file, "example_matrix") print(mat2) #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] #> [1,]    1    4    7   10 #> [2,]    2    5    8   11 #> [3,]    3    6    9   12  # Verify equality all.equal(mat, mat2) #> [1] TRUE  unlink(file)

what: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: Reads attribute associated HDF5 object (dataset group).

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
code: h5_read_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object (dataset group) attribute attached . attribute Name attribute read.

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: numeric, character, raw vector/array.

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: Numeric attributes read numeric (double). String attributes read character. 1-byte OPAQUE attributes read raw.

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Create a dummy dataset h5_write(file, "data", 1:5) #> NULL  # Attach an attribute h5_write_attr(file, "data", "unit", "meters", dims = NULL) #> NULL  # Read the attribute unit <- h5_read_attr(file, "data", "unit") print(unit) #> [1] "meters"  unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
text: Returns low-level HDF5 storage type dataset (e.g., "INT", "FLOAT", "STRING"). allows inspecting file storage type reading data R.

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
code: h5_typeof(file, name)

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset.

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
text: string representing HDF5 storage type.

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Write integers h5_write(file, "integers", 1:5, dtype = "integer") #> NULL # Write doubles h5_write(file, "doubles", c(1.1, 2.2)) #> NULL  # Check types h5_typeof(file, "integers") # "INT" #> [1] "INT" h5_typeof(file, "doubles")  # "DOUBLE" #> [1] "DOUBLE"  unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
text: Returns low-level HDF5 storage type attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
code: h5_typeof_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object attached . attribute Name attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
text: string representing HDF5 storage type.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "data", 1) #> NULL  h5_write_attr(file, "data", "meta", "info", dims = NULL) #> NULL h5_typeof_attr(file, "data", "meta") # "STRING" #> [1] "STRING"  unlink(file)

what: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
text: Writes R object HDF5 file dataset. file created exist. Handles dimension transposition automatically.

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
code: h5_write(   file,   name,   data,   dtype = typeof(data),   dims = length(data),   compress = TRUE )

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset (e.g., "/data/matrix"). data R object write. Supported: numeric, integer, logical, character, raw. dtype target HDF5 data type. Defaults typeof(data). Options: "double", "integer", "logical", "character", "opaque", "float", etc. dims integer vector specifying dimensions, NULL scalar. Defaults dim(data) exists, length(data) otherwise. compress logical integer 0-9. TRUE (default), compression level 5 used. FALSE 0, compression used. integer 1-9 specifies zlib compression level directly.

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # 1. Write a vector as a double h5_write(file, "vec_double", c(1.5, 2.5, 3.5)) #> NULL  # 2. Write integers with compression h5_write(file, "vec_int_compressed", 1:1000, dtype = "integer", compress = TRUE) #> NULL  # 3. Write integers, enforcing integer storage on disk (uncompressed) h5_write(file, "vec_int", 1:10, dtype = "integer") #> NULL  # 4. Write a 3D array (uncompressed) arr <- array(1:24, dim = c(2, 3, 4)) h5_write(file, "3d_array", arr) #> NULL  # 5. Write a raw vector (as 1-byte OPAQUE) h5_write(file, "raw_data", as.raw(c(0x01, 0xFF, 0x10)), dtype = "opaque") #> NULL  # Verify types h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE) #> [1] "3d_array"           "raw_data"           "vec_double"         #> [4] "vec_int"            "vec_int_compressed" h5_typeof(file, "raw_data") # "OPAQUE" #> [1] "OPAQUE"  unlink(file)

what: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
text: Writes R object attribute existing HDF5 object.

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
code: h5_write_attr(   file,   name,   attribute,   data,   dtype = typeof(data),   dims = length(data) )

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object attach attribute (e.g., "/data"). attribute name attribute create. data R object write. Supported: numeric, integer, logical, character, raw. dtype target HDF5 data type. Defaults typeof(data). dims integer vector specifying dimensions, NULL scalar. Defaults dim(data) length(data).

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Create a group/dataset first h5_write(file, "my_dataset", 1:10) #> NULL  # Write scalar attributes h5_write_attr(file, "my_dataset", "version", "1.0", dims = NULL) #> NULL h5_write_attr(file, "my_dataset", "timestamp", 123456, dtype = "integer", dims = NULL) #> NULL  # Write vector attributes h5_write_attr(file, "my_dataset", "range", c(0, 100)) #> NULL  h5_ls_attr(file, "my_dataset") #> [1] "version"   "timestamp" "range"     unlink(file)

what: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
title: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
text: h5lite package provides simple, lightweight, user-friendly interface reading writing HDF5 files. designed R users want save load R objects (vectors, matrices, arrays) HDF5 file without needing understand low-level details HDF5 C API.

title: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
text: h5lite handles common tasks automatically: Saving R objects correct dimensions. Reading data back R matrices arrays. Reading writing R factor objects native HDF5 ENUM types. Automatically overwriting data creating parent groups. Writing compressed datasets. Safely reading numeric types without integer overflow. Reading writing R raw vectors. package uses HDF5 library developed HDF Group (https://www.hdfgroup.org/).

title: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
text: Maintainer: Daniel P. Smith dansmith01@gmail.com
